description: From Middle French présupposition, from Latin praesuppositio, from the past participle stem of praesuppōnere (“to presuppose”).

entries.meaning: An assumption made beforehand; a preliminary conjecture or speculation.
examples: He made one cardinal error in his presuppositions about the relation between language and perception, but in this he was far from alone.

entries.meaning: (linguistics) An assumption or belief implicit in an utterance or other use of language.
